_header: Not mans steven but good will
Note:
Walther (1963)
XWalther, Hans. Proverbia sententiaque latinitatis medii aevi. 6 vols. Göttingen, 1963-69, no. 18723; Walther (1969)
XWalther, Hans. Initia carmina ac versuum medii aevi posterioris latinorum. Göttingen, 1959; 2nd ed. 1969, no. 12222.
_description: Four lines translating ‘Non vox set votum. Non musica cordula set cor’, etc., a tag in the Fasciculus Morum, which precedes it

Bod410.Transcription:
No mannys steuen but good wyllNo murth of mouth but hit styllNo
                    cry but loue ne other berenys murth ne song to here

BodLauMis111.Transcription:
No mannis stewene but goud willeNo murthe of mouth but herte
                    stylleNo cry but loue ne other berenys murthe ne song to l
                    god to here

BodLauMis213.Transcription:
No monnes stewene but good wyllno myrth of mouth but hert
                    stilleno cry but loue ne other bereNys myrth ne song god to
                    here

BodRawC670.Transcription:
Ne monnes steuen but gode wylleNo murthe of mouth but herte
                    stylleNo cry but love ne oþer bereNys murthe ny song god to
                    here
BodRawC670.Editions:
Silverstein,  Theodore,
                        ed.  
             Medieval English Lyrics.
         York Medieval Texts. London: Edw. Arnold, 1971: 76.
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978: 142-3.

OxfLinLat52.Transcription:
No mowthes steuyn but gode willno myrth of mouth but hert
                    stillno crie but loue ne oþer bereis myrth ne song god to
                    here

CamGon71.Transcription:
Nogth man steuen bot god wyllnogth myrth of mouth bot hert
                    stillNo cry bot loue ne noȝer lereþis myrth soundes in godes
                    here

CamGon364.Transcription:
No mowthys steuene but good wylleno myth of monyth but herte
                    stylleno cri but loue neoȝir bererysmerthe no song god to
                    here

CamStJohn159.Transcription:
No man steuyn bot god with o gud wylleno myrthe of mothe
                    bot hert styllno erye bot I lufe no oþer bereNys myrthe no songe
                    god to here

NLS18721.Transcription:
Nout mannis steuene but good willeNout mirthe of mout but herte
                    stilleNon loud cri ne non hey layBut priue bidding is godis
                    pay
NLS18721.Note:
Appears separately in John Grimestone’s sermon notes, preceded by
                        ‘Non vox set votum non musica cordula set
                    cor’.
NLS18721.Editions:
Wilson,  Edward. 
             A Descriptive Index of the English Lyrics in John of Grimestone’s
                Preaching Book.
Medium Ævum Monographs
         n.s. 2. Oxford, 1973: 28.

EDU82.Transcription:
Noo mannes steuen but god wyllnoo myrth of mowth but hert
                    styllNoo crye but love ne nother bereNys ne song god to
                    here

Lincoln44.Transcription:
Non mannes steune bot god willNo morþe of moþe but hert
                    stylleNo crys but houe no oþer berenys murthe ne songe to
                    here
Lincoln44.Note:
Translates preceding Latin aphorism, ‘Nam deus non
                        verborum…’; written as prose.

Spalding.Transcription:
No man steuen bot god wyleNo myrth of mouth bot hert styllNo cry
                    bot lofe non oþer bere & cetera

WorcF19.Transcription:
non mannis steuene bot gode willeNon murthe of mowþe bot herte
                    stille
WorcF19.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             A Register of Middle English Religious & Didactic Verse.
         2 vols. London: Oxford University Press for the Bibliographical
            Society: 1916-20: 1.450.
